Bleeding: Apply direct pressure on the wound with a clean cloth.
Keep applying pressure until the bleeding stops.
If bleeding is severe, keep the injured area elevated.
Burns: Remove the person from the heat source.
Cool the burn with cool (not ice-cold) running water for at least 10 minutes.
Cover the burn with a clean, non-stick dressing.
Avoid breaking blisters and do not apply ointments.
Choking: Ask if the person can speak or cough.
If not, perform 5 back blows between the shoulder blades.
If still choking, perform 5 abdominal thrusts.
Repeat until the object is dislodged or help arrives.
Drowning: Remove the person from water and lay them on their back.
Check for breathing and start CPR if necessary.
Place them in the recovery position if they start breathing.
Electric Shock: Turn off the power source before touching the person.
Check if they are breathing and start CPR if needed.
Cover burns with a sterile, non-stick bandage.
Fracture: Keep the injured area still and do not attempt to move it.
Apply a splint if trained to do so.
Use ice packs to reduce swelling.
Head Injury: Keep the person still and calm.
Apply a cold compress to reduce swelling.
Monitor for signs of concussion (confusion, vomiting, unconsciousness).
Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen.
Heart Attack: Make the person sit and stay calm.
If they are unconscious, begin CPR if trained.
Heat Stroke: Move the person to a cool, shaded area.
Cool their body with water, ice packs, or fans.
Have them sip cool water if they are conscious.
Call for medical help if they become unconscious.
Poisoning: Call the Poison Control Center or emergency services.
Do not induce vomiting unless instructed by a medical professional.
If the person is unconscious, check for breathing and perform CPR if necessary.
Provide information about the poison if possible.
Seizure: Stay calm and protect the person from injury.
Do not hold them down or put anything in their mouth.
Turn them onto their side to help breathing.
Call emergency services if the seizure lasts more than 5 minutes.
Severe Allergic Reaction (Anaphylaxis): If the person has an epinephrine auto-injector (EpiPen), help them use it.
Lay the person flat and elevate their legs if possible.
Monitor breathing and be prepared to start CPR if needed.
Snake Bite: Keep the victim calm and still to slow the spread of venom.
Remove tight clothing and jewelry near the bite area.
Do not suck out the venom or apply ice.
Stroke: Remember FAST: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call emergency services.
Lay the person down with their head slightly elevated.
Do not give them food or water.
